Article 55 was consequently aooroved by the Supreme Council in its present form,(II) The Supreme Council then proceeded to consider a report by Marshal Foch's Commission (A.J.163 attached) on the proposal of the Conference of Foreign Ministers and Ambassadors in London to reduce the number of Commissions to be set up Under Articles 45, 48, 49, 50, 51 and 52 of the Treaty, together with an alternative report by the British representatives on Marshal Foch's Commission, whichwas supported by the Italian and Japanese naval representatives.On this subject the Supreme Council reached the.'following decisions :-(i) th*t the military, naval and air Commissions at Constantinople should be separate and that Marshal Fosh*s military and nava.t Commission should meet to prepare the alterations in the reserved articles of the Treaty, for communication to the Drafting Committoe without coming back to the Supreme Council,ant(2) that Marshal Fochfs Commission should further consider the question whether the number and cost of these commissions could in any case bi? reduced by utilising the services-of--the AUJjBd-jrdUjtary, naval, and air attaches or other Allied Officers at Constantinople,It will be observed that, while the question of principle was decided by the Supreme Council, the material for the detailed alterations in the Treaty involved by this decision, will be communicated direct to the Drafting Committee, (ili) The Supreme Council next considered a passage in the Report of Marshal Foch1s Commission dealing with a suggestion by Field Marshal Sir Henry Vilaon that a clause should be Inserted in the Treaty of Peace with Turkey assuring to the Army of Occupation the right of requisition.The Commission^ proposal "as accepted that in view of the delicate nature of the question raised by the exercise of this right, the Drafting Committee should be asked to propose the terms in which the right of requisition as applied to the zone of the Straits should be inserted in the Treaty of Peace, as well as to determine in which part of the Treaty the relative stipulations ought to appear.,You will observe that this involves action by the Drafting Committee.(IV) The Supreme Council then considered the question of lake Derkos and approved the following recommendations byMarshal Foch's Commission" (i) That the basi*i of Lake Darkos, as Allies to dispose of an effectual means of action against the capital of the Ottoman Empire in case of troubles there.This solution being accepted, the Chataldja lines would be entirely within the demilitarised zone."You will be able to obtain the map from the Military or Political Section. 16.5I understand that you are In touch with the British representative on the Geographical Commission.
